title: Junglers, if you ever, once, ever utter the phrase "I need leash, no leash no gank"
body:
You have no business jungling ever. Period.

No jungler should NEED a leash first of all, if you can't solo clear half a jg quadrant without any assistance then you have zero clue how to properly manage the camp aggro and micro your way around so you take the least dmg possible. There is not one single champion that cannot do this. Not one.

Secondly, if you refuse to play the game properly after that and avoid a lane just because it didn't leash you when you fail to communicate effectively what you would like your opening 4 minutes to go like as the jg you should be perma'd on the spot for trolling. Period.

Stop acting like little bitches just becasue you fools can't figure out how to play your role properly, just stop playing it at all and do us all a favor.

Troll the games just because you don't know where or how to start in the jg... sheez.

replies.body:
There are no words for how absurd this post is. Not giving your jungler a leash results in them being way far behind the other jungler, makes them incredibly susceptible to an invade, and makes them be at a much lower health if they go for a gank after 3 camps.

I honestly don't blame any jungler who avoids your lane if you refuse to leash. Playing jungle is all about maximizing your resources. If a laner isn't willing to provide a leash, which is literally NO cost to the laner, then I wouldn't trust that guy to carry the game. That kind of person is usually so ignorant and toxic that they'll go on tilt over the tiniest things.

> [{quoted}](name=Randomonium,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=2zef7p4Q,comment-id=0007,timestamp=2016-10-05T00:03:51.640+0000)

>If a laner isn't willing to provide a leash, which is literally NO cost to the laner

What if they have some kind of Cheese planned?  Or what if they're in a difficult lane and getting the early push will help them win it?  There are circumstances where a jungler should be able to adapt.

You can provide a minor leash and still get to lane before the minion wave hits.  Spawn timers are specifically designed to allow for side laners to provide a leash and still get to lane by the time the minion waves collide.  Even if you get to the lane a couple seconds after your opponent it is still possible to outpush him and get level 2 first.  Furthermore, its also very easy to avoid level 2 or level 3 all ins if you play correctly.

If you are trying to cheese or are extremely worried about your lane then you should be communicating that with your jungler so he knows to start on the opposite side.  Not communicating and then ignoring his pings at 1:30 is simply not acceptable.

If you don't leash for your jungler that really sets them behind as I described above and severely gimps his ability to provide early pressure relief.  That's an extremely bad gameplan if you know you're already going into a bad lane matchup.

I've never seen a jungler tilt if his laner communicated with him.  The only time the whole "no leash, no gank" stuff comes up is when you don't say a damn thing, the jungler thinks you're going to give him a leash, and you just ignore him.

I think you phrased this post extremely poorly.  Your main concept of there being no place for a jungler to ever say "no leash, no gank" is good.  However, the rest of the post basically calling anyone who can't jungle without a leash total garbage who shouldn't be playing jungle.  A person has to learn jungling somehow and there are only a select few champions who can easily jungle without a leash.  Most of the other ones you either have to be experienced with both the champion and the jungle roll or you need a leash to not fall behind.  While it is possible to solo the jungle with anyone, is it really a good thing to do?  If you solo on a champ who struggles early and get invaded you are 100% screwed.

If I am jungling and don't get a leash then don't expect a gank in the early game.  This isn't because I'm toxic or a trash player, it is because a gank from me with the champions I typically play will most likely result in me being too low on mana/hp or being 2 levels behind.  The only way a gank like that ever works is if the enemy is just asking to be ganked by pushing to the tower without a ward while being low on heath or mana.

I believe what "Truly Not Gay" was trying to say to you, before you got all butthurt and attacked while trying to defend your opinion, is that though a lot of champions have the CAPABILITY to clear a whole couple of camps alone, with minimal to no team participation required, it is still COMMON FLIPPIN' COURTESY to take 3 damn seconds of your time to help that champion clear the jungle FASTER. What they were pointing out had NOTHING to do with their individual mastery of their champion. What they were pointing out is that a leash is like a "you scratch my back, I scratch yours" kind of deal. It's common sense to anyone who plays the game beyond a Co-Op vs AI level. (And even then, they learn to understand this.)

If you don't have the common courtesy to give up 3 flippin' seconds of your time to leash the jungler's first camp, then why would you expect them to use any more of THEIR time to help you, specifically. A jungler sayin' "no leash, no gank" does not immediately mean they are trolling you. Nor is it immediately saying they want to lose the game. It is them tellin' you "since you couldn't help me with a simple task, how can I expect you to be cooperative with ganks?"

In situations where someone doesn't leash for a jungler, that jungler will usually go to snowball a lane OTHER THAN the laner who refused to leash. Does that mean he wants you to lose? No. Does that mean he thinks ignoring you would help you win? No. It means that they don't feel they can trust you. If giving up 3 seconds of your time is too much of a hassle for you, how could one possibly trust that you won't leave them hanging in ganks? How could one possibly trust you to help with dragon control? They can't.

I don't care what champion my junglers are playing, nor do I care about how well they can clear the jungle alone. If you are starting your jungle route on my side of the map, assuming I'm either one of the bot laners or the top laners, I'm giving you a leash. UNLESS YOU ARE SHACO. That is literally the ONLY time I will not leash for you because your boxes will do that in my place. Why? Because it's common flippin' courtesy to do so and 3 seconds of my time WILL NOT COST ME A DAMN THING.
